text: 1 was rather saddened to hear some of the comments made by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges), so before I address myself to what I have planned to say I should like to respond to three of his statements. His suggestion that by cutting back the supporting parent's benefits to some groups of recipients the Government would be able to fund fewer crisis centres absolutely astonishes me. He himself said that he has visited centres. So have I, over many years. What one sees in many of the women's refuges is a very large number of married women who find themselves in crisis. It was only yesterday that I was told that domestic Violence is at "last being recognised as growing at such a rate that the demands on these centres will undoubtedly grow still further, until we as a society can do something about lessening the level of domestic violence. I refute the suggestion that the single parent's benefit somehow or other helps to fill up our refuges. The supporting parent's benefit goes mostly to separated and divorced women and women who are not able to gain support from a spouse. Also, the honourable member referred insultingly to the women' who work in the women's refuges in Australia. Back in the mid-70s, I was fortunate in being able to visit one of the first women's refuges in Australia, if not the first, run by a collective. That was the Elsie Women's Refuge in Sydney. From that day to this, I have, never ceased to be impressed by the amazing dedication of women who work in refuges. Also, I have seen many other refuges that are. being run by churches, migrant groups, youth workers and others. The dedication of refuge workers is something that most of us never realise until we visit a centre. I also think that the distress that the women and the children, men and the young people, experience when they go into refuges is not understood by ml:\ny of us. May I finally comment on just one other area to which the honourable member for Petrie addressed himself. He referred to some projects that were not being funded under this scheme. I know that the projects which the Western Australian committee has rejected for inclusion' under this program are being funded at supported accommo" terms of dation a-sistance program levels, by the Commonwealth. The Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill represents the first concerted attempt by a Comser- monwealth government to rationalise and improve the many schemes and programs which exist throughout Australia to help people without homes. The Bill is the outcome of nearly 18 months of consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, non-government organisations, advisory bodies and the providers of services to homeless people. I should like to start by congratulating the Hon. Keith Wilson, the Western Australian Minister for Community Services, and all the other people who have been involved in devising the program in Western Australia, my home State, for the constructive and co-operative attitude they have shown during the negotiations. The Commonwealth has been involved in the provision of assistance to homeless people since 1974. 'Programs have included the youth services scheme; the family support services scheme, the children's services program, the crisis accommodation for families' in distress program, and the homeless persons assistance program. Some of these schemes were administered by the Commonwealth, and others by the States. At the same time, the States were also funding and running other similar schemes. The result was a hotchpotch of legislation in which financial and physical resources were in grave danger of missing their most appropriate and effective mark. In 1982, the Federal and State Welfare Ministers agreed on the need to review all the Commonwealth and Commonwealth-State programs with the aim or rationalising the co-ordination, the delivery and the general standard of services to the homeless. The review, as the House has already heard from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), was finally set in motion by this Government early in its first term. It came to be known as the Review of Crisis and Youth Accommodation 'and was carried out un'der the auspices of the Departments of Social Security, Housing and Construction, and Education and Youth Affairs. The review found that the existing system was inadequate and illogical, unco-ordinated, complex and poorly funded. It is the recommended remedy to this situation that we are discussing here today. The Minister's second reading speech 'contains a concise account of the details of the new arrangements, but I would still like to draw attention to some of the particularly noteworthy points. The key elements of the legislation is its flexibility, and I am pleased to see that this has been acknowledged with approval by the Opposition. The aim is to provide homeless peoplethat is, people who lack adequate shelter or support Jrom both family and. the community-with help in the short, medium and even longer term. The legislation recognises that homeless people have various requirements, from emergency accommodation in a crisis to help with child and health care and financial counselling. Some people need immediate access to short term accommodation and intensive support services such as those found in refuges for women and youths. Others need a less intensive level of support and might be helped by spending time in a halfway house or a hostel. The three sub-programs which make up the Bill give a clear indication of the breadth of the new arrangements. The first section deals with youth supported accommodation and aims to provide services for young people between the ages of 12 and 25. This area has already been allocated $830,000 in the 1984-85 financial year to cover the first six months of the program. In the 1985-86 full financial year it will attract $1.66m. The second section involves the women's emergency services program, which was first established by this Government in 1983 with an allocation of $4m. This program will continue to cater for women with and without dependants who need to get out of violent or threatening domestic situations. I will be addressing myself to this section of the Bill a little later. The third section of the Bill deals with the general supported accommodation program which , provides for services to those men, women and children who are permanently or temporarily homeless but who do not fit clearly or practically within the youth ot women's supported accommbdation program. One of the points which the Mihister has stressed about the applicability of this Bill is that the three broad sub-programs extend the range of the. program rather than limit it. Women, for instance, may be assisted under anyone of the three different sections, depending on the specific needs and problems being catered for. Likewise, services for young people could be eligible for funding under either the women's emergency services program, the youth supported accommodati'onprogram, or even, in special circumstances, the general program. '' . Asa Western Australian, I am particularly pleased to be. able to report to the House that the Western Australian State Government has accepted the terms and conditions contained in this Bill, and a supported accommodation assistance program began on 1 January this year. The State Minister, Mr Wilson, has also agreed that Western Australia will operate under the national guidelines, and will shortly be advising this Government's Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) about Western Australia's advisory structures. A proposal to allocate $700,000 worth of Commonwealth funds is currently being examined by the Western Australian Commonwealth-State joint committee, and the Federal Government has agreed to continue funding, at levels equivalent to the. new program, the eight homeless persons assistance program projects which the State excluded from funding under the new arrangements. Western Australia has also agreed to meet Commonwealth matching requirements by 1988-89. We already have 15 services approved under the youth section programs, 14 approved as women's emergency services and 22 services approved under the general sub-program. New services are currently under consideration for inclusion in all three sub-programs, Madam Deputy Speaker, I do not want to take up too much of the time of the House. However, I do want to return briefly to the women's emergency services sub-program, and acknowledge some of the work which has been done in this area. As I commented earlier, the Commonwealth has been involved in the provision of assistance to homeless people since 1974, and it was at this time that I first got to know some of the women around this country who were. organising refuges for women. Many of them are still involved in refuge work-so their credentials and track records referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Petrie, have truly been set down and established-having spent more than 10 years withoutadeqJat- funding, without any organisa:tional back-up, and without the human ana;capital resources so desperately needed. I want to-pay tribute to these' \Vomen, and particularly to the Western Austnllian refuge workers who hav- had to battle the 'odds with hostile conservative State governments as well as cope with all the other difficulties. No-one is suggesting that the supported accommodation assistance program will solve all trfunding problems faced by women's refugys. Nevertheless, the proposals are a vast improvement on the old system. We will have security of funding, with a legislative base. There will be the flexibility for women's refuges to choose the subprogram which best suits their specific needs. There will be co-ordination and all supported accommodation for women, including child care in women's refuges. We will have the scope to cater for a broad range of women in crisis, whether they are chronically homeless or in a temporary crisis, and refuges will be able to focus more on services assisting women escaping violent or otherwise,intolerable domestic situations. Funds have been provided this financial year for improving salaries and operating subsidies. More money has been promised for 1985-86 for new services and increased staffing. For the first time we have guaranteed indexed increases in the salary component or grants to reflect the growth of wages. We have funds for program evaluation and a whole new approach to the development of a needs based system which recognises the importance of involving the service providers in planning for needs and priorities. A particularly significant point is that the new lationwill, for the first time, bring community based rape and incest crisis centres under the umbrella of Commonwealth assistance. The Bill and the complementary crisis accommodation program provide both for capital and recurrent funding, and the major component of recurrent costs-that is, an estimated 80 per cent of all SAAP funds-will be fOf salary subsidies to workers who provide support services such as counselling, information, referral and follow-up. Support services under the women's sub-program will extend to advice, assistance and advocacy in regard to legal problems, housing, health, child care and income support. Madam Deputy Speaker, I want to end on a cautionary note. As workers in the field know, one of the major causes of women needing refuges is domestic violence-now recognised as a major problem with grave social implications-which in turn is all too often a factor in family proverty. The problems are not going to diminish' quickly. The Australian Institute qf Fa-iil>,'Studies,1 h:a$ just found that there were about 382,000 families; with three-quarters of a million cHildren, livl--g'in poverty in 1982. I suggest that a 'number of those would be on supporting parents benefits and' the thought of cutting them off is quite horHtying. There is no room for complacency'over thdnew provisions under discussion here today, as I know the Minister would b- the first to agree. Thy Bill represents an important first step, particularly in an administrative sense, butl would urge con'tinuing vigilance on the, part 'of the service providers, the funding administrators and all the Mihisters concerned. With' this legislation in place, Australia at last has the chance to develop a supported accommodation program which will provide effective and' appropriate assistance to the homeless.

Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Title: NOES
text: Ifthere is a failing of the Hawke Labor Government it is that it does not remind the Australian people enough of the monstrous injustices and maladministration of the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government and its coalition predecessors. The wasted opportunities, the narrow, short-sighted, quick fix and the patronage of decaying social and economic structures are all well-established hallmarks of Liberal-National Party policy in government. If this country is suffering from unemployment, we must look at those who ran this country for 31 of the last 36 years, or nearly nine out of every ten years in that time. It is the ineptitude of these former conservative governments which allowed our factories to turn into industrial museums and which, with the ordinary taxpayers' money, through investment allowances and other ineptitudes, sent billions of dollars of work and industrial development to the United States of America, Germany, Britain and Japan. It was the former Ministers of these Liberal-National Party governments who now criticise this Government's short period of office, which is still spoken of in months and not years. It is the Liberal-National Party governments which have led this country into the economic quicksand. The billions of dollars of interest on overseas borrowings that the taxpayer must now bear are a direct result of the gross ineptitude of the Fraser Government and its Ministers, many of whom now sit on the Opposition front and back benches pretending to be economic saints and gurus. The Hawke Government, by any comparison, has achieved an economic recovery unparalleled in the Australian post-war experience. In a mere 22 months, 341,000 jobs have been created because of .direct government involvement in programs such as the community employment program, through the success of the prices and income accord, through the consultation and consensus processes of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Business Council of Australia and the now mostly forgotten but underestimated success of the National Economic Summit Conference. It took the Fraser Government seven years to achieve the same thing while it was trying to fight inflation first. What a joke! While it was fighting inflation first by putting people out of work and raking up massive overseas borrowings for future generations to support, the inflation rate kept going up and up and the unemployment figures kept going up and up until they exceeded three-quarters of a million people, with many hundreds of thousands more in hidden unemployIt has ment. Even with such job growth and economic growth, industrial disputation, except in neofascist governed States such as Queensland, is at a record low in Australia today. I will not go through all the economic comparisons now. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), during Question Time this week, has already magnificently exposed the glaring comparison by any standards between the success achieved by this Government and the failure of the former Liberal-National Party Government and its remnants sitting opposite. If one really stretched mercy one could begin to forgive those opposite for their gross ineptitude, but what they have done to the lives of millions of Australians today is quite unforgivable because it was done with their full knowledge while in government. Up to three million people in Australia now live in poverty. The life of one person in every five is restricted in opportunity, basic comfort; security, nutrition, health and justice. Every time the issue of poverty is raised by a member of the Government, those on the other side, in their arrogance, smirk. Those same people who so sanctimoniously took their Christian Bible in their hands for the swearing in ceremony in this House as a badge of their righteousness deny the first principles of Christianity-care for your fellow human beings, especially those who cannot protect themselves. Their golden rule is not 'Do unto others as you would have them do unto you'; the golden rule of the members of the Liberal and National parties is 'Whoever has the gold makes the rules'. Poverty is the greatest blight and restriction upon this country. It affects us all, directly or indirectly, whether rich or poor. Before those opposite chortle 'Why doesn't the Government not do something', let us look at the extent of poverty as it grew under their patronage. In 1968 the top 10 per cent of income earners in Australia had 10 times the income of the bottom 10 per cent. By 1982, a mere 14 years later, for every $1,000 paid to the poor, the rich received $56,000. Apart from three years under the Whitlam Government, when there were significant steps to reduce poverty in this country, the onus for this regressive distribution of wealth lies upon those opposite. They cannot get away from it. One has only to go back to the beginning of this week to see that they are not prepared even to admit their mistakes or to redress any of the injustices they have caused. Five times in two years and, as late as the beginning of this week, they have voted against the bottom of the harbour Bills which are designed, as they know only too well, to recoup the tax revenue kept from the people of Australia by those opposite because of their inability or unwillingness to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion. Honourable members opposite are always saying how concerned they are about the Australian family. The tax avoidance and evasion that they presided over costs the average Australian family about $43 a week, but the Opposition in this House does not care. I return to the figures I mentioned earlier. In 1968 the top 10 per cent of income earners had 10 times the income of the bottom 10 per cent. By 1982, for every $1,000 paid to the poor, the rich received $56,000. To put it another way, the wealthiest 2,500 Australians now own as much of this country's wealth as the poorest two and a half million. Nearly 800,000 children are included amongst the poorest two and a hal f million people in this country. To gain an idea of the magnitude of the maldistribution of this common wealth of Australia that has occurred under those opposite, if those two and a half million poorest Australians stood hand in hand the line would stretch from Sydney to Perth. I ask honourable members to think about that. A line of people over 3,000 kilometres long would stretch all the way from Sydney to Perth. If the wealthiest 2,500 Australians, who own as much wealth as those two and a half million Australians at the bottom end of the income scale, stood hand in hand they would be lucky to reach a distance of three kilometres, the distance between a couple of average suburban railway stations. That is the extent of the maldistribution of wealth in this country. Those opposite, the protectors, the puppets of the greedy tax avoiders and evaders, have deliberately ignored the plight of those in poverty in Australia today. Speaker: Mr STAPLES
Title: NOES
text: Information released this week by the Institute of Family Studies shows that between 1979 and 1982 there has been a 54.4 per cent increase in the number of two-parent families and a 38.6 per cent increase in one-parent families living below the poverty line. In those three years there has been a monstrous increase in the number of both two-parent and single parent families living below the poverty line in Australia. In my electorate of Jagajaga, more than $190,000 was distributed in emergency relief last year. On average, each applicant received $30 on four occasions throughout the year. That means that nearly 2,000 families are living on the poor box poverty line. One cannot get much lower than that if one has to ask not just for a pension or a benefit, which one is entitled to, but for a handout from the poor box. Can honourable members imagine the degradation and the extent of the poverty that people in this situation have to face? It is deplorable and it is the duty of this House and of everybody else to ensure that the load is lifted from the poor of this country and shared more evenly. Today thousands of Australian children will go to bed hungry. That is a fact. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) well knows the extent of poverty in his electorate and the problems that mothers have to go through. As he has told me at other times, women have had to sell themselves into prostitution to get food for their children. It is just not good enough. Because of the extremes of poverty many parents of young people will expose themselves to great risks in this country today, tomorrow and for years to come unless we do something. Poverty is a fact of life. Where the next meal will come from, where the next piece of clothing will come from, are problems that affect many people in Australia today. It is our national responsibility to address poverty, its causes and effects, right now. It is not just the job of this Government, a job which is well under way; it is the job of the Opposition, both Houses of Parliament, and the community of Australia to recognise the needs that exist today of those millions of our fellow citizens in poverty. In less than one thousand days we will celebrate the bicentenary of European settlement in this country. Leading up to our bicentennial year in 1988 is the International Year of the Homeless in 1987. I, for one, welcome the passage through this House of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill, after years of token pilot schemes for the homeless under Liberal-National Party governments. The Year of the Homeless in 1987 should remind us that if we do not effectively address ourselves to attaching the highest priority to the issue of poverty over the next thousand days, we will have little of real value to celebrate. Taxation reform is the obvious and most powerful vehicle to address this issue. As my good colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), with his usual eloquence, pointed out only last night in this debate, the facts are clear. The payas-you-earn taxpayer has been copping it in the neck, and those on the lowest incomes are affected the most because of the limitations of their disposable incomes. In various ways these Appropriation Bills address aspects of poverty, but today the duty is upon us all on both sides of this House, in the other place, in parliaments throughout Australia, in local councils, communities and families and as individual Australians to act now to stop the poverty that exists in this country, otherwise our bicentenary year will be a very hollow affair despite all the crackers, fireworks, television jingles, and so on. Poverty should be a political issue in this country, an issue which governments can quite comfortably go to the electorate on and speak strongly on. Voters not in poverty should show concern for their friends and neighbours and those people they do not know who are in great poverty in this country. To assist in raising poverty as an election issue, a real political issue, in this House and in the community, I will be organising a poverty summit in my electorate, starting on 28 April, to look at different facets of poverty. The poverty summit will continue throughout the year. The first session, on Sunday, 28 April, will focus on poverty and tax reform. I invite all honourable and members of the community to attend that poverty summit, because true tax reform will do more to alleviate poverty in this country and to share the common wealth of Australia. People should think of the words 'Commonwealth of Australia' as meaning to share the common wealth of Australia more equitably.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: NOES
text: It is the fundamental duty of the government of any nation to protect its population and territorial integrity against armed aggression and occupation by an aggressor. That should be the prime obligation of any government, including the present Government. All the welfare programs that can be dreamt up are worthless and will become meaningless if this country is not in a position to defend its territory and defend all Australians. Territorial defence must also, of necessity, include our ability to keep open sea lanes and maintain an ability to trade and resupply. Events over the past six months have brought into sharp focus the shortcomings of the present Government, along with the most serious consequences for any Australian Government, present or future, in its failure farsightedly to plan the future defence posture of this country. Minority interest factions within the Australian Labor Party have, deliberately or otherwise, managed to reduce contemporary debate on issues affecting the security of our region to narrow, and in many ways irrelevant, dimensions. Planning for defence against possible future threats has been consumed by the need to justify our traditional alliances rather than concentrating on the best and most affordable defence for Australia over the next 15 years and well into the next century. The plight of our defence forces has been adequately covered by my colleague the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr White) and others on this side and I do not intend to dwell on our present state of unreadiness. Of immediate concern to many is our alliance with the only great military power and hitherto reliable military ally to which we might turn in the event of a threat to our national integrity. That very great country is, of course, the United States of America. Our relationship with this politically stable friend and ally has deteriorated rapidly in recent times under this apology for a government. Integral to our approach to defence of this country should be an awareness of the fact that it takes an unprepared democracy a great deal of time to react to threats, real or perceived. It is therefore a delusion-a potentially disastrous delusion-to be as soft on defence as the present Government, or to rely on an absence of identifiable, real or perceived threats for the time being. Most Australians must deplore the Government's weak-kneed reactionary stances to what under a coalition government would have been normal, everyday exchanges and co-operation with our United States ally. The MX missile testing crisis could have occurred only under this Government. The actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government during that episode are well reported, and the fact that he had to be bailed out by the United States Administration, because of internal Labor Party faction fighting, brought no credit to him or his Government. Strains on ANZUS, although initiated by the New Zealand Government, have reached, or possibly gone beyond, breaking point because of the ineptitude of this socialist Prime Minister and his Government. Australia's role in rail-gun research, where we have led the world, is under threat. Our participation in some of the research for the United States strategic defence not just under threat but has been abandoned to other nations in the free world, to' our eternal shame. That abandonment is not the outcome of reasoned debate, but because one or more factions of the Labor Party would not have a bar of it. Under the present Government, Australia has clearly signalled that it is unable to take its place alongside its allies in assuming responsibility for the future defence of our region, and has seriously cast doubt upon our resolve to be able to defend our own people. For the first time in decades, debate on defence is newsworthy, albeit for the wrong reasons. To the extent that the Government has been tested in this context in public forums, it has failed miserably. Meanwhile, accepting the responsibility thrust on it by the Western alliance, the United States is maintaining major naval and military bases in Japan, the Philippines and Diego Garcia, which enable it to sustain a very considerable deterrence against aggression in our region, in particular the western Pacific and eastern Indian Ocean regions. Political instablity in the Philippines and the expiration of the lease for Subic Bay in 1991, just six years hence, have monumental implications for our region and our security. While there may be no identifiable threat in our region for the time being, it is not implausible to come to the conclusion that that state of affairs exists because of the deterrence provided by the substantial United States presence and our alliance with that country. Planning for the 1990s and beyond must surely take into account the contingency that the United States will no longer be able to operate from Clark Base and Subic Bay in the Philippines. In that unthinkable event, the Soviet presence in Cam Ranh Bay will be of even more critical significance. It must be a serious possibility that United States facilities which will enable it to operate naval and air forces in the southern Pacific may have to contract to Guam and Hawaii. Given that possible scenario, and the fact that the nearest United States naval and air base is limited to Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, outright defence of our shipping lanes and eastern and western seaboards will become even more the responsibility of Australia. The great tragedy, for those of us who regard our defences as of both paramount importance and inseparable from a workable alliance with the United States, is this socialist Government's capitulation to those who vociferously advocate the removal of all joint Australia-United States faciliinitiative is ties on our soil. If that conclusion needs corroboration, we need look no further back than last weekend. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) made a virtue out of his Government's withdrawal of an offer by the coalition government to the United States to consider the use of naval facilities at Cockburn Sound in his own State of Western Australia. He did so in a particular context, of course; in a debate before school kids. Instead of showing leadership and farsightedness, he close the easy way and disqualified his Party and his Government from an option which could and should be explored before identifiable needs and threats arise. Regional and national defence history has shown that it can be fatal to wait until one's head is on the block before making plans and canvassing all conceivable options. The Minister, his Government and his Party have lost their heads, all because of a possible lack of electoral popularity in the face of the loss of a Senate seat to the Nuclear Disarmament Party and a Palm Sunday rally or two around the country. In employing the argument that the offer made by the coalition in government somehow detracts from a commitment to maximum self-reliance in defence, the Minister, of necessity, opens up to question the continued co-operation with the United States in joint facilities in this country. That may not have been the intention of the Minister in choosing the words he used last weekend, but it is at once the logical and undesirable consequences of those words. The Minister cannot have it both ways. He cannot say, on the one hand, that joint facilities of one kind may remain and, on the other, that other and new. joint facilities cannot even be discussed as being desirable for all time to come. If he thinks that is consistent in logic, he has given the mad Left of his Party a whole new line of argument. If he does not and his gloating over the withdrawal of future access to the Stirling naval base facilities is a one-off decision, the ister for Defence is guilty of mortgaging the future of this country's defences by denying even the planning involved in making a joint naval facility on our western seaboard a goer. In a major conflict, regional defence will almost inevitably involve the United States, failing which, quite clearly, there will be no regional defence capable of meeting all future threats. In pandering to the Australian Labor Party's reactionaries who see evil in our enduring friendship with the United States, spanning 40 or more years, the Government is forgoing, or is on the brink on forgoing, any claim to the good will of the only democratic super-power of modern times. Above all, the Government is now in a position that prevents it from contingency planning for future United States military bases on Australian soil as may become essential for Australia's defence. In the context of a debate on defence and our defence posture, it is necessary to comment on our economic performance as a country. A sound economy is an indispensable prerequisite to our ability to defend our populace against possible external aggression. With Australia's defence efforts and planning being inhibited by poor economic performance and prospects under this Government, it is necessary to comment on that performance and those prospects. Time and again it has been necessary to restate the lack of certainty created in the private sector by the Government's inability to state its clear and firm intentions in relation to economic matters and taxation. All too often, this uncertainty is due to ad hockery and on the run economic decision making. Under pressure the Prime Minister has shown a propensity to make pronouncements which have not been thought through for their impact on decision taking in the wealth creating private sector. It is well known that the Prime Minister decided to hold a tax summit in July of this year following what was at best a throwaway comment by an unqualified radio commentator in Perth during the last election campaign. That decision served a useful purpose in that it got the Prime Minister and his Government off the hook in the absence of an ALP policy on tax in the runup to that election. Since then, of course, the sky has been darkened by kites being flown by the Prime Minister, other Ministers and ALP factions galore. In the eclipse-like gloom that exists as a result of the Prime Minister's tax summit folly, priMin- vatedecision takers are groping in the dark for want of certainty as to the direction of the Government on taxation policy. Let us look at some of the promised events in the next few months which are bound to exacerbate the profound uncertainty with which the wealth creating sector will have to grapple. As I have already mentioned, there is the tax summit. There is the prospect of another wage indexation hearing later in the year. There are likely to be across the board wage increases for increased productivity. There will almost certainly be an extension of employment deflating redundancy extravagance' into even more and more awards. We are likely to be confronted with occupational safety imposts which are likely to break new and unexplored ground. We are almost certain to cop an extension of obligatory non-contributory superannuation funds at the prompting of and with the connivance of the Hawke Government, which will cost employers an additional $11 a week per employee. We certainly will have to face up to renegotiation of wage fixing guidelines between the Government and-guess who?-its masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions and all that that may mean. We will be confronted by new wage relativity claims of the type mentioned in the grievance debate yesterday. Then there will be observance of theaptJy named trilogy. I say it is aptly named because the Concise Oxford Dictionary tells uS that a trilogy is 'a set of three tragedies to be performed in immediate succession'. The Prime Minister's trilogy is surely about tragedies. Debate interrupted.

AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY: NA . Mr MAHER-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the significance for Australia and the Australian economy of the .recent visit of the Chinese official, Mr Hu Yaobang?

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: SIGNIFICANCE OF VISIT BY MR HU
text: I thank the honourable member'for Lowe for his question without notice. He never misses; he is consistent. Unfortunately, only IS minutes of Question Time remain, which does not allow me to do justice to the very significant possibilities that have been opened up for Australia. I will content myself, very briefly, with making some observations. The first is based upon the fact that I still think it is the case that not enough people in this country and in other parts of the world appreciate the significance of what is occurring in China at present. As I have said, we are witnessing a quiet revolution in China, whereby the enormous initiative and enterprise bf hundreds of millions of Chinese people are being released in a way in which they have not been in the last 40 years. Associated with that change in their economic approach to production and distribution, they are also opening their country to the West. It is extremely fortunate that, because of the in- . itiative that was taken by Mr Whitlam and maintained, to his credit, under the Prime Ministership of Malcolm Fraser, we have been able, in recognising these changes that have taken place in China in recent years, to take advantage of the special relationship that I think is developing between Australia and China. There are so many areas in which this relationship has now been manifested that I cannot exhaustively deal with them all. Let me deal with some of the more obviously important ones. There is the iron and steel initiative, which itself is manifested in a number of ways. It is manifested in the increase in the exports of iron ore and semifi-ished products to China, which increased by 53 per cent last year. There will be joint ventures in Australia and in China between enterprises of the two countries in the iron and steel industry. There wjll be the transfer of the very considerable. advances in Australian technology in this field. There is also the significant increase in the export of manganese from Australia to China. I imagine that, within this year, we will see the finalisation of some very significant developmeq.ts in Australia to which reference has already been made. In a period of some 14 or 15 months, those developments have been quite remarkable. It is a matter of great importance for Australia, an importance which will be understood and appreciated by my friends in one corner of the chamberYAOBANG Dr KLUGMAN - Cockies' corner.

Speaker: Mr HAWKE
Title: SIGNIFICANCE OF VISIT BY MR HU
text: It is referred to irreverently as cockies' corner. However it is described, I know it is appreciated because I had the opportunity of introducing some of those gentlemen to Hu Yaobang and I was appreciative of the opportunity of doing that. We are now replicating in the wool industry the concept and the approach that have been so successful in the iron and steel industry. That will be of great importance for Australia because we will now have extensive co-operation at all levels of the wool industry, from the export of raw wool and semi-finished products to our technology going to China to help it with the development of its textile industry and the development of its flocks. So we will have an enormous, extensive and comprehensive degree of cooperation between the two countries in the wool industry. I believe that we will also be able to do a great deal in the non-ferrous metal areas and, if I may so, in the agricultural industry generally. We have confirmed the extensive degree of cooperation that will take place in the areas of research and the application to China of so much of the development in agricultural and applied research that is occurring within Australia. I believe that one of the very significant areas of importance for China and, in a flow on sense, for Australia will be the acceptance by Mr Hu Yaobang of our offer to send an expert team to China to look at its transport net(ds. Sir Peter Abeles will head that team. I believe that there will be an opportunity to take to China the experience of Australia in transport economics, which is so important. We have had experience in the areas of rail, road, shipping and aviation in a very large country. I believe that we will be able to be of considerable assistance to China and there will be a very valuable spin-off for Australia. Having said all those things in the economic sphere, I want to tie it together, in conclusion, and say that what is tremendously important is the fact that we see emerging the capacity of two very important countries in the region of different social systems and different backgrounds to be able to work together constructively not only in the economic field but also in the cultural field. Ultimately, the great benefit of this will be not so much just in the economic field but I believe it will make a great contribution to the cause of regional peace and stability. NA

It will be April of next year before this matter will be before the Commission in any possibly substantive way involving a reflection of the devaluation effect in the consumer price index. As I have said-I give the Australian community the reassurance that the Treasurer and I have given-this Government will not allow the very substantial benefits that will flow to the Australian economy from the current devaluation to be dissipated by an inflationary spira\. With respect to the wages area, that matter will not be substantially before the Commission for almost 12 months. While those on the other side, on their past record, have given no evidence of their ca-· pacity in economic management, I will just give them this lesson: It is an exercise in futility to make a decision about a situation, the elements of which one does not know, 12 months in advance. text: by leave-On 9 October, the Parliamentary Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee tabled its report entitled 'Australia and ASEAN-Challenges and Opportunities'. It is my task today, on behalf of the Government, to respond to that report. Allow me first, however, to pay a tribute to the former Chairman of the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, Bill Morrison, who presented the report to the House and whose personal stamp is, I believe, very clearly on it. As honourable members will know, Bill Morrison will shortly be in a position, as Ambassador to Indonesia, to contribute further to the development of Australia's interests in the gion. The Government looks forward to a continuation of his vigorous and constructive advice on the development of Australia's inteI;ests. The report is a most welcome review of developments in the Association of South East Asian Nations region of interest to Australia, of Australia's policies towards the region and of our future prospects there. It is constructive in tone and makes a· number of thoughtful and helpful suggestions about how our relations may be developed further. I should like to address briefly the report's major themes. I shall then seek leave to have a schedule of responses to the Committee's individual recommendations iricorporated in Hansard. The Government fully shares the Committee's view that 'no other part of the world promises to be of more consistent importance to Australia has than the region of East and South East Asia, and that the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Natiohs form a significant part of thi- most economically dynamic region'. The Government's policies have been consistently deinveloped upon that recognition. The development of our relations with the countries of ASEAN will continue to be given very' high priority under this Government. . The Committee· has identified quite comprehensively the range of national interestpolitical, defence and strategic, economic, immigration and cultural-that Australia has in its near region, in particular in ASEAN. These matters constitute an intricate web of interlocking interests and concerns that link Australia and ASEAN. These elements are usually best not dealt with in isolation, as a change in one element can 'significantly affect other parts of the whole but, for ease of presentation today, I should like to single out a number of strands which will serve to outline our policies to this point, 'and out future intentions. . It' is well known that this Government has given very high priority to security matters in the region, most notably in seeking to contribute to. a settlement in Cambodia. Much has been said lately against the Government's efforts in this direction. We have never said it would be easy or quick. B,ut it is undeniable that a negotiated settlement, while still sadly a possibility rather than an imminent reality, would be the single greatest contribution to the stability of a region of prime strategic importance to Au.stralia. As I have said before, the longer the Cambodian conflict continues, the more likely it is that there will come about that which we fear most-the intrusions of great power tensions into our immediate region' re- through the increasing presence of external military forces and the exercise of force through proxies. Cambodia remains the greatest source of unresolved tension and instability in our region. The Australian Government therefore has a responsibility to continue to pursue the means by which a just solution might be found and the daily suffering of the Cambodian people brought to an end. The Committee has quite cogently pointed out that we are in general agreement with the ASEAN states over Cambodia. ASEAN, like Australia, has always condemned the violation of Cambodia's sovereignty and called for'the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces. We share 'concern at the dangers of regional instability and heightened great power corripetition and tensions caused by the conflict in C-mbodia. We also share a common concern at the burdens on the Cambodian people and their neighbours consequent upon the movement of refugees and displaced persons from and within Indo-China. Indeed, our concern as a . major donor and country of asylum is direct and beyond.dispute. Beyond these shared concerns, the Committee notes that Australia has striven to make clear other implications of the situation which we would be unwise to ignore. In particular, we are concerned that the Khmer Rouge, led by Pol· Pot, remains the largest and most effective component of the resistance coalition. We believe that to champion Pol Pot, however indirectly, is to place; not remove, obstacles to a just settlement. We have consistently warned of the dangers inherent in the present situation of recurring violence, which results in a continuation of suffering in Cambodia. It increases prospects of a widening conflict; it encourages tendencies towards a regional arms race; and it exacerbates the long term problems arising from Vietnam's international isolation and dependence on the Soviet Union. The Committee observes that our regional policies have not been fully understood by ASEAN and that consultation is of prime importance. I would observe, in turn, that it is true that our cies on Cambodia have on occasion been misunderstood or perhaps misconstrued, but I would suggest that our clear and consistent enunciation of our concerns and the rationale behind them since 1983 have greatlyimproved the acceptance of our approach with ASEAN. Our role has been modest but it has been persistent. The single thread which unites all our efforts over the past two years has been the call for dialogue and compromise. It is to this end that I have spoken to leaders on all sides and at all distances from Cambodia. The Committee has made balanced and comprehensive judgments on the regional issues facing Australia, and I undertake that the Government will continue its efforts to search for a just Cambodian settlement and the development of Australia's relations with Vietnam in the cautious terms supported in the report. It is not in our own interests or those of our region for us to place barriers between ourselves and the countries of Indo-China. As I mentioned earlier, the Government fully recognises the importance of close consultation with the ASEAN countries. I have taken many opportunities to consult with ASEAN leaders. I greatly value their vie:ws and will continue to seek a them. I am sensitive to the vital importance of the situation in Cambodia to them and most especially to Thailand. There have been a number of points during our efforts on Cambodia at which we have reassured Thailand of our continuing friendship and our commitment to its security and well-being. I shall continue to provide these assurances unhesitatingly. I look forward to discussions with all of my ASEAN colleagues during the post ministerial conference to be held this year in Kuala Lumpur. I have no doubt that the matter of Cambodia will again be high on the agenda. The Government is very much aware of the profound economic changes identified by the Committee that are taking place in the ASEAN region. While the ASEAN countries continue to face major economic challenges resulting from factors such as population size and growth rate and the associated crises of employment and poverty, and also structural weaknesses which make them vulnerable to trends in the international market, the weight of evidence suggests that most of the ASEAN economies have performed well so far and promise to perform well in the years ahead. These changes in the ASEAN region have important implications for us and the future economic health of Australia. The key question is that of our economic relevance to the ASEAN countries and indeed, the broader region. I have previously drawn attention to the fact polithat the years ahead will call for flexibility and innovation on the part of Australian business and labour, matched by vision and determination on the part of government. The rest of the world does not owe us a living, nor particularly do the countries of the region, including the ASEAN states, few of whom have been endowed with the bounty of natural resources comparable to those we have in Australia. It is up to Australians, individually and collectively-politicians, business and employees-to provide the initiative and skills which will enable us to seize the economic opportunities in our region and, in so doing, contribute to and benefit from growth in the region. The bottom line for Australia is that, while the ASEAN countries will probably continue to offer expanding economic opportunities for nOll-ASEAN countries, we have no mortgage on these opportunities and will have to work hard to take advantage of them. If Australia is seriously intent on demonstrating its regional credentials it should have, or be able to develop, advantages of proximity and familiarity. It will be vitally important for the future of Australia that there is growing awareness of and discussion within the broader, community of Australia's future economic directions. The Government will do what it can to facilitate this process. Indeed, the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is a very worthy contribution to this. But we also look to the universities, the media, and the business and union groupings to contribute to this process. The Committee commented on discussions held on concepts of economic' co-operation in the Pacific region. The Governmenfs interest in promoting discussion of the economic changes in our region and exploring the processes of Pacific economic co-operation was reflected in our decision in mid-1984 to establish a National Pacific Cooperation Committee. The main activities of this Committee are to examine Australia's interests in possible paths towards economic co-operation with its neighbours in Asia and the Pacific and to co-ordinate future Australian participati.on in the Pacific economic co-operation process. Its membership is drawn from a cross-section of the Australian community and includes senior representatives of business, the unions, academic and the Public Service. As I noted last year, the Committee is a concrete expression of the Government's determination to stimulate community awareness of the economic importance to Australia of the Asia-Pacific region. We have continually emphasised the need for Australia to come to terms with and be involved in the possibilities and challenges offered by the fastestgrowing region in the world. Australia has initiated consultations with regional countries, including the ASEAN countries', to encourage cooperative and mutually supportive approaches to multilateral trade problems. Progress has been pleasing and a frank and open exchange on issues of concern has developed. Another major theme of the report is that of the distinctive identity of Australians in this region of the world, and the related necessity for developing human contacts between Australians and citizens of the ASEAN countries. I agree with the Committee that co-operation with ASEAN should be based on the recognition that 'Australia's political culture and processes are substantially different from those of the ASEAN states and that these differences are unlikely to diminish'. These differences are real but they do not diminish nor disguise our responsibilities and place in the region. It is our home. We cannot ignore the implications of our geographical position, nor. the qesire of our people to live in a region of harmony and rewarding international relationships. We are directly affected if the rivalry of great powers threatens peace in our region. We are directly concerned if our friends and neighbours are destabilised because of continuing tensions. We also bear many of. the direct consequences of tensions and conflict in the region. Our long-standing and close association with ASEAN and the host of common interests which we share with our ASEAN neighbours compel us to work at further development of mutual awareness and understanding at allleyels. The promotion of mutual awareness and common interests is an area in which the Government's record is very strong. Australia's successful and extensive immigration and refugee programs have helped ·foster an interchange on the most personal level between Australia and ASEAN. The migrants who come from ASEAN countries make a significant contribution to Australia's increasingly cosmopolitan society. The Government has stressed the importance of people-topeople contacts between Australia and ASEAN. To that end, this Government has broadened the range of sponsored visitor and exchange schemes through which social, technical, and cultural exchanges are fostered. Another important aspect of the Government's policies to promote mutual awareness is Australia's commitment to Asian studies. Australia already ranks among the best centres for Asian studies in the world, particularly with regard to Indonesia. There is, however, always room for improvement and I am pleased, therefore, that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and I have agreed to the establishment of a working party to examine the concept of the formation of an Asian studies council, as recommended by the Committee. The Government's private overseas studentpolicy also plays a major role, reflected in the high proportion of . students from ASEAN countries. As well as serving the development needs of their own countries, overseas students also take home with them an intimate understanding of Australia which helps to improve knowledge of Australia in the ASEAN countries. This Government is convinced of the value of fostering mutual awareness and common interests with the people of the ASEAN coun. tries, and our record is testimony to our dedication in this respect. That dedication will not diminish under this Government. In conclusion, I again thank the Committee for its detailed and thoughtful contribution on the subject of ASEAN-Australia relations. As will be evident from the schedule which I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard, a good deal of detailed consideration has already been given to the Committee's recommendations and much more is to follow. (a) and (b) The Government recognizes that the impact of freight rates on the competitive position of Australian exporters is a complex matter. Not only is it difficult to isolate freight rates from other elements which determine the competitiveness of Australia's exporters but other factors such as the importance of the commodity in the liner trade and the conditions of access to the market can minimize the effect freight rates have on the volum.e to be exported. Consideration is being given to how more comprehensive current data on comparative freight rates can be collated. However, even data such as this will need to be used with caution in drawing generally applicable conclusions about the impact of freight rates. Freight rates in the ASEAN trades are subject to constantly changing factors such as the exporter's cOPlpetitive situation in the market and the general level of competition in the shipping route. The Government is addressing the issue of shipping and related transport costs for Australian exporters by its decision to establish two industry task forces, one to inquire into shore-based shipping costs and one to review Australia's overseas liner shipping arrangements. 7. (c) It is the Government's policy that a more equitable share of Australian cargoes should be carried on Australian owned or controlled and Australian staffed ships, and accordingly measures have been implemented to assist Australian flag shipping to become more internationally competitive and to place ANL on a more commercial footing. We have agreed with ASEAN countries to keep each other more fully informed on shipping policy developments. The Australian objective is to ensure that the interests of Australian exporters and those of Australian flag operators will not be adversely affected, but at the same time recognising the need to be sensitive to the aspirations of the ASEAN countries regarding issues that may be raised. 7. The Government believes that serious consideration needs to be given to possible means to co-ordinate nationally initiatives 'in Asian studies. (b) "Australia will need to continue to approach human rights issues in ASEAN countries with sensitivity. Attempting to draw direct associations between the extension of aid and human rights performances of regional governments would not, except in unusual circumstances, be appropriate." Response The Government's approach to human rights questions in ASEAN countries takes fully into account the reality recognised by the Committee that Australia's ability to influence human rights developments will depend in part on the quality of Australia's multilateral and bilateral reRecommendations lationships in the region. The Government accords human rights a high priority in its foreign policy and is strongly committed to the promotion and protection of human rights. This together with the high level of community interest and concern in human rights matters, ensures that the Government meets its responsibility to respond to violations of human rights wherever these occur. The Government believes however that it is essential to act constructively on human rights matters and that Australia's human rights concerns can be most effectively pursued in the context of mutual understanding and sound bilateral relations. The Government appreciates the Committee's view that Australia needs to approach human rights issues in ASEAN countries with sensitivity. As a country with a different social, cultural and economic history, working within a different political structure and system of values from that of its neighbours Australia must pursue its human rights objectives in the ASEAN region with tact, determination, sensitivity and persistence. The Government agrees with the Committee's view that the provision of development assistance should not inextricably be linked to a country's performance in human rights. The Government does not believe that aid should be automatically withheld from countries whose human rights record is poor. The adoption of such measures is most likely to inflict punishment on the poorest and most exposed who would be innocent of the Response human rights abuses perpetrated by their Governments. Nevertheless there will be scope for aid to be directed in a way which serves also to encourage positive developments in human rights. This possibility should be taken into account in developing proposals for development assistance. NA Recommendations 5. I made a statement on the report of the 'Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence when our former colleague on the Committee, Mr Morrison, tabled it in the House some time ago. I join the Minister in wishing Mr Morrison all the very best of success in his new appointment. In my remarks today I will address the tabling statement of the Minister and aspects of his observations in the attached statement of Government responses which has just been tabled. The Committee, in its findings, endeavoured' to criticise the assumption that we should distance Australia from ASEAN in favour of Vietnam. Avery real and understandable view was growing up in the community that this GoVernment and this Minister seemed to place much more emphasis on good relationships with Vietnam than on good relationships with ASEAN countries. As I have said, the Committee, in its the proposals For student 'trade findings, endeavoured to criticise that assumption. We need to recall that ASEAN diplomacy had convinced the Third World, which voted 100 plus in favour of the ASEAN position at the United Nations, that peace and neutrality could be restored only by an internationally supervised settlement in Cambodia, not a settlement imposed by the continuing application of Vietnamese force-150,000 Vietnamese troops still occupy Cambodia-and not a settlement induced by Pol Pot, whose Cambodian forces still hold out and who, quite rightly, the Minister and the Government criticised. I just add parenthetically, that it was a Labor Government which initially recognised Pol Pot when he first came to power and boasted about it at the time. ASEAN saw the need for a third force, a force based on giving a priority not to military effort but to political effort, a force which could creditably speak for the Cambodian people. ASEAN supResponse ported Prince Sihanouk and Son Sann and succeeded in getting agreement to the seating at the United Nations of Sihanouk instead of Pol Pot and instead of the puppet Government in Phnom Penh. This achievement was considerable and it has not been given sufficient credit by this Government or the Minister. It was at that stage that the Foreign Minister entered the scene and proceeded to muddy the international waters by taking a public line designed to reflect discredibility on ASEAN and more credibility on Vietnam. We all know, the history of the overtures to Hanoi, the warnings to ASEAN, the embracing of Hanoi, the questioning concern of ASEAN. £t got so bad that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to step in and patch up the quarrel. It was against this background that the Joint Committee made its observations. Basically, Austra,lia can contribute but ASEAN carries the main burden. We exaggerated differences between ASEAN members in their approach to the problem. Government spokesmen drew distinctions between Indonesia and Singapore, and between Thailand and Indonesia, and implies that those differences reflected support for our diplomacy and criticism .. Government spokesmen equated differences between the Hawke Government and ASEAN with differences between the Fraser Government and ASEAN over civil aviation and protection. Last year, speaking on this aspect, I said: It is inevitable that there will be divergent viewpoints emanating from Australia and ASEAN on economic issues in particular. We are not saying, nor is the Government Committee, nor is ASEAN, that differences are a sign of frailty. They may be a sign of strength. Clearly, as there is a hierarchy of sensitivities, there is a corresponding hierarchy of permissible differences. The Fraser Government became involved in a strong dialogue on economic issues and civil aviation ..Paragraph 3 of the foreword of the Committee's Report states: . . . Title: AUSTRALIAN ASSISTANCE TO ASEAN
text: by.1eave-I wish to comment on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, entitled 'Australia and ASEAN-Challenges and Opportunities'. I shall limit my remarks to the response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Government to the recommendation on conflicts in Indo-China. Recommendation 3 (d) of the Committee's report states: That some uncertainty has arisen in ASEAN suggests to the Committee that Australia's regional policies have not been consistently propounded and explained as extensively as might be desirable. This makes consultation of prime importance. It is in both Australia's and ASEAN's interests to avoid major discord between them over policies towards regional security issues. The report goes on to state: The evidence: does suggest, however, that if Australia wishes to take a consistent interest in the security of the Southeast Asian region overall, it will need to emphasise clearly that in seeking to explore ways of enhancing prospects for regional security the cautious development of policies towards Indo-China will not be pursued at the expense of long-term relations with ASEAN. That is a very significant part of the Committee's report. The Minister flew in the face of the recommendations of that report in visiting Vietnam. In visiting that country he did all the things that the Committee report warned against. The report is all the more significant because it is a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, a committee of both members of the Government and members of the Opposition. Too little attention is given in this House, in the media and in the community generally, to reports of Committees where both sides of the Parliament sit down in the community interest. This report is all the more significant for that,' and it is even more significant that the Minister flew in the face of the all-party report. As the previous speaker. on this side has said, the Minister's trip to Indo-China was disastrous. It has upset ASEAN,our important neighbours, and it has upset its attitude to Australia: I believe it has endangered our foreign policy. The Minister's trip to Vietnam, at a time when Vietnamese troops were in Thailand, an ASEAN country, has endangered not only our, relationship with Thailand but our relationship with ASEAN. The Minister's trip was naive and stupid and it flew in the face of the report of the Joint Committee of October last year. I find it surprising and amazing that the Minister for Foreign Affairs of this country would visit Vietnam at a time when Vietnamese troops were over the border,ofThailand. I conclude by looking at the human rights aspect of Vietnam. Vietnam has hundreds of thousands of people in so-called re-education camps, but which are actually concentration ,camps. That is an enormous denial of human rights in our region. I think the Minister's visit was a total disaster and, as I have said, flew in the face of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The House and the nation should be advised of the importance of small business to the welfare of the community and to the welfare of the citizens of the seat of Deakin in Victoria. Many commentators, when writing of the condition of democratic capitalism in the late twentieth century, leave the impression that the bulk of the work force is employed in large organisations. In fact, less than one per cent of businesses in Australia employ 100 people or more; 99.4 per cent of firms employ less than 100 people; and less than one per cent employ between 50 and 99 people. Dickensian and vulgar Marxist notions of a world organised into vast, urban factory conglomerates have failed to materialise. Facts such as these will not stop the Socialist Len faction of the Government parading its ritual fantasies, but that should make the rest of us aware of the importance of small and medium businesses to the national interest. The key fact is that 92 per cent of businesses in Australia employ less than 10 people. So much for Marx and his disciples. In the light of these facts, what I propose is that a small business impact statement be attached to each government Act and regulation. The House will be astonished to learn that in the past 20 years the people of Australia and the firms where they work have been subjected tosome 50,000 government Acts and regulations, and most of them are broken down into dozens of sections, sub-sections, wheretofores and the rest. Small business is unable to employ teams of company lawyers, chartered accountants and logicians on its staff to decipher all these rules and regulations. Small is business has to get on with the job of producing the goods, servicing the market, paying its taxes and trying to meet the wages bill and insurance payments for workers compensation. The current situation in which small businesses are being drained of working capital by paying sales tax on revenue before they receive the revenue is a disgrace. Most of the new jobs which have come onto the market in the past 10 years are in the small business area, but they have been created in spite of, rather than because of, the activities of government. I smile when I hear Government leaders piously claim that they have created jobs. They might just as well claim that they have created sunshine. It is now the practice of Federal governments to look at the financial impact of their Bills. I am suggesting that a small business impact statement should be made a matter of priority. Let us look at some of the pieces of legislation before the House recently-the customs tariff proposals, the excise tariff proposals, the Bass Strait levy proposals, the Bounty (Injection Moulding) Bill and others. Each of these has a direct impact on a group of small businesses, or on all of them. There are potential costs in money and time in each of these pieces of legislation. There are investment consequences and, more importantly, there are consequences affecting Jobs. Yet half of this Parliament would not have the faintest idea how their pet schemes, pr,oposals and Bills affect small business and the jobs it creates. The Parliament needs to be told in clear terms of the impact of the. Government's actions. From such kno,:¥ledge a certain wisdom might grow.

Speaker: Mr CONQUEST
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Earlier this week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) delivered to this House statistics cleverly and selectively designed to suggest that Queensland's economy was at a dangerous ebb. Those figures were misleading, especially when one compares the statistical evidence over a more realistic period. There is no doubt that over a more relevant five-year period Queensland has been the fastest growing State in Australia. While several factors contributed to this growth, its main impetus was gained through the major once-off boost to the economy through the development of new export coal mines and port facilities. The major infrastructure associated with such work lifted Queensland's economy to a point where on all key indicators it was performing better than the national average. This is shown in the following figures, all of which relate to average annual growth rates for the five-year period from 30 June 1979 to 30 June 1984: Queensland's population grew at a rate of 2.3 per cent compared with a national average of 1.4 per cent; Queensland's labour force grew at a rate of 3.4 per cent, compared with a national average of 2 per cent; employment in Queensland grew at a rate of 2.8 per cent compared with a national average of 1.4 per cent; new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises grew by 16 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average. of 11.6 per cent, which was a four-year period only; the value of new buildings ClPproved grew by 16.9 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 12.5 per cent; motor vehicle registrations grew by 5.3 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 3.7 per cent; and retail sales grew by 12 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 10.8 per cent. While Queensland's growth over the last five years has been spectacular, the current economic situation in Queensland reflects unfavourable national and international factors. This also has to be coupled with the completion of the expansion of Queensland's mineral developments. Despite the temporary problems we are currently facing, the underlying economic and financial strength of Queensland provides a sound basis for steady growth in the longer term. These growth prospects are enhanced by the Queensland Government's positive policy of encouraging economic development through expansion of the private sector. The current economic situation in Queensland is influenced by two main factorsthe completion of the expansion phase of· Queensland's massive coal resources, and the world economic situation, especially with regard to sugar and base metals. The effect of the completionof mining and port facilities was anticipated. However, the simultaneous problems in the world sugar market and low world prices for base metals, particularly copper, compounded the effect on Queensland's economic growth. Long term benefits are now being achieved through increased revenues and job opportunities associated with the operational phase. However, it was always accepted that the level of economic expansion would, inevitably,. return. more to the Australian average, although on a considerably improved base. It is in this context that Queensland's current level of economic performance must be assessed. The key point is that while many of our current economic indicators are below their previous high levels, they are still above the national average. They are above the contribution to Australia's performance that could be expected on the basis of population share. Compared with our population share of l6.l per cent, the latest figures show that Queensland contributes 17.4 per cent of new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises; 24.5 per cent of housing completions and 23 per cent of all building completions in Australia; and 23.7 per cent of Australia's exports. These are positive indicators of the State's growth and potential. One of the sources of major growth in the economy of Queensland, and Australia, in the future will continue to be oUr vast mineral resources. These include about 50 per cent of Australia's proven recoverable reserves of coal, bauxite, silver, lead and zinc. Recent studies of our international competitiveness in coal and aluminium confirm that our substantial cost advantages will ensure a prominent position in international markets as demand expands.
